block.p: Open Houses

WEDNESDAY -- A self-guided tour of the homes of interior designers and their clients on the Upper East Side will be followed by a party at 3 p.m. at Baccarat, 625 Madison Avenue (59th Street). The day is a benefit for the women's shelter that Lenox Hill Neighborhood House runs at the Park Avenue Armory. The tour will begin at 10:30 a.m. with coffee and refreshments at the neighborhood house, 331 East 70th Street. Tickets, $100, from (212) 744-5022, ext. 1282.

Cocktails for Common Cause

WEDNESDAY -- The New York chapter of Common Cause will raise money for its work with a cocktail party at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South. Among those to be honored at the party are Donna Dees-Thomases, Elise Richman and Rebecca Peters, for their roles in the Million Mom March, and Robert C. Newman, for his years of service to Common Cause. The evening begins at 6. Tickets, $100, from (800) 300-8707.
Helping Cambodian Villages

THURSDAY -- The Nginn Karet Foundation for Cambodia will give a dinner at Cipriani, 110 East 42nd Street, to raise money for relief programs in five Cambodian villages in the Angkor region of the country. A cocktails reception at 7 will be followed by a Cambodian dinner and Cambodian music, singing and dancing. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 861-3792.
Yiddish Theater Lives On

THURSDAY -- Theodore Bikel and Eleanor Reissa will perform songs and scenes at a reception celebrating the 85th season of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater in New York. The event at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue (92d Street), will raise money for the theater and its educational programs, which include free and reduced-price tickets for students, the elderly and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Drinks and hors d'oeuvres at 6:30 will be followed by the performance at 7:45. The evening will end with coffee and dessert. Tickets, $250, from (212) 213-2120.
A Home of the Hudson River School

OCT. 10 -- Friends of Olana will give a black-tie dinner at the Century Club, 7 West 43d Street, to raise money for the preservation of Olana in Hudson, N.Y., the tiled and turreted 19th-century home of the painter Frederic Edwin Church. The event will also support public education programs. Drinks and a silent auction at 7, will be followed by dinner at 8. Tickets, $500, from (212) 327-0785.
Grand Central Cabaret

OCT. 11 -- Jennifer Holliday will sing at a black-tie dinner in Grand Central Terminal to support education, research and medical programs at the Weill Cornell Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital and the Weill Medical College. The event begins with a cocktail reception at 7, with dinner and the show at 8. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 685-1095.
Hayworth Gala

OCT. 11 -- The annual Rita Hayworth Gala, which raises money for programs of the Alzheimer's Association, will be given at the Waldorf-Astoria. The pop duo of Ashford and Simpson will perform. The evening will begin with a cocktail reception at 6:30. Dinner will be at 8, with dancing to the music of the Stingers Orchestra to follow. Black tie. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 843-1712.
For Cancer Research

OCT. 12 -- The Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, which supports cancer research at the Weill Cornell Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital will give a fund-raising dinner at the Pierre. Nancy Brinker, the founder of the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, will be honored. Cocktails at 6, followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $500, from (212) 213-1166.
Friends of the Carousel

OCT. 14 -- The Prospect Park Alliance's Carousel Ball will raise money to put a new roof on the carousel in Prospect Park and to help keep the cost of a ride on the carousel at 50 cents. The wooden carousel was built in 1912, and moved to the park from its original home, at Coney Island, in 1952. The evening, a black-tie event in a tent at the carousel (guests enter Prospect Park at Empire and Flatbush Avenues), will honor Dr. Edison Jackson, the president of Medgar Evers College, and Charles Hamm, the president of Independence Community Bank and Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank. Drinks at 6:30 will be followed by dinner and dancing at 8. Tickets, $250, from (718) 965-8964.
Trading Toe Shoes for Street Shoes

OCT. 16 -- A performance and dinner at the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College will raise money for Career Transition for Dancers, an organization which provides job counseling, scholarships and other programs for professional dancers moving out of dance to other careers. The evening will begin with the performance at 7, with dinner to follow at the Essex House. There will also be a live auction for South American cruise tickets for two and other prizes. Transportation will be provided between the theater and the dinner. Tickets, $500, from (212) 582-6690.
An Education in Art

OCT. 17 -- The New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture will raise money for its programs and student scholarships at a dinner, exhibition and silent auction of artworks. The event will take place at the school, 8 West Eighth Street (Fifth Avenue). Drinks at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8. Dancing and dessert will begin at 9. Tickets, $350, or $75 for entry at 9 for dessert and dancing, from (212) 685-1095.
